qas.question: What type of ceramic art was popular from the 8th to the 18th century in the art of Islam?
Which ceramic glazing was developed by those potters which were Islamic?
Where would one find the earliest examples of opaque glazes in the Muslim world?
Around when were the first opaque glazes developed?
What was used in Islamic art from the 800's to the 1800's?
What is often formed into utilitarian pottery?
What ceramic glazing was adopted by islamic potters?
Where can you find the latest examples of opaque glazes in the Muslim world?
What was a center for innovative ceramic pottery in the 14th and 15th century?

context: Between the 8th and 18th centuries, the use of <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>glazed ceramics<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> was prevalent in Islamic art, usually assuming the form of elaborate pottery. <a1_0><b7_0>Tin-opacified glazing<b7_0/><a1_0/> was one of the earliest new technologies developed by the Islamic potters. The first Islamic opaque glazes can be found as blue-painted ware in <a2_0><b8_0>Basra<b8_0/><a2_0/>, dating to around the <a3_0>8th century<a3_0/>. Another contribution was the development of stone-paste ceramics, originating from <a4_0>9th century Iraq<a4_0/>. Other centers for innovative ceramic pottery in the Old world included Fustat (from 975 to 1075), Damascus (from 1100 to around 1600) and <b9_0>Tabriz<b9_0/> (from 1470 to 1550).
